title: 104_hr1083
content: The "Travel and Tourism Relief Act of 1995" may be cited as the short title. Certain travel agents are not treated as employees under this Act. The "Travel and Tourism Relief Act of 1995" defines a qualified travel agent as an individual providing services for a travel agency appointed by commercial airlines or affiliated with CLIA. The "Travel and Tourism Relief Act of 1995" defines a qualified travel agent as an individual whose remuneration is based on sales or output, and who works under a written contract as a non-employee for tax purposes. The section heading of the Code is amended to reflect this definition. The "Travel and Tourism Relief Act of 1995" redefines a qualified travel agent as someone whose remuneration is based on sales, working under a written contract as a non-employee for tax purposes. The amendments made by this Act include adding travel agents to certain sections of the Code. Effective date applies to services performed after enactment. The "Travel and Tourism Relief Act of 1995" redefines a qualified travel agent as someone whose remuneration is based on sales, working under a written contract as a non-employee for tax purposes. The Act also amends section 274(n) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to increase the deduction for business meals and entertainment expenses from 50% to 80%. Additionally, the Act repeals the scheduled increase in tax on fuel used in commercial aviation. Effective date applies to services performed after enactment. The "Travel and Tourism Relief Act of 1995" redefines a qualified travel agent and increases the deduction for business meals and entertainment expenses. It also repeals the scheduled increase in tax on fuel used in commercial aviation, with an effective date of September 30, 1995. SEC. 5. DEDUCTION FOR PROMOTION OF TOURISM IN THE UNITED STATES. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a deduction for expenses promoting tourism to the United States by non-residents. Effective for amounts paid or incurred after the enactment date. SEC. 6. DEDUCTION ALLOWED FOR CONVENTIONS ON FOREIGN-FLAGGED CRUISE SHIPS. SEC. 6. DEDUCTION ALLOWED FOR CONVENTIONS ON FOREIGN-FLAGGED CRUISE SHIPS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a deduction for conventions on foreign-flagged cruise ships. Effective for cruises starting after the enactment of this Act.
